issue.title: Payments/Escrow app

labels.name: product
labels.description: Discussion about integration of new features

issue.body:
We can install a Payments / Escrow app along with the Conviction Voting app, and when a proposal is approved, transfer the money to the escrow before before it is sent to the beneficiary. I'm going to use the Escrow app and Payments app indistinctly until we decide which name fits better the app.

When a proposal is created, it is associated with an escrowed payment in the Escrow app. A reviewer address and an arbitrator address are probably already in place since those can be Aragon permissions (`REVIEW_ESCROW_ROLE` and `ARBITRATE_ESCROW_ROLE`) over the Escrow app. So DAOs can define fixed reviewers and arbitrators for all proposals, or set up granular permissions adding custom reviewers and arbitrators per each proposal.

When a proposal has been approved, the money is transferred to the escrow payment contract (payments don't go to the escrow app directly, but to an independent contract), and the funds are released by the reviewer to the beneficiary when they consider the task is complete.

The arbitrary can be the Aragon Court, the same community via voting, or event a single entity. Beneficiary can raise a dispute to the arbitrator in case the reviewer do not release the funds appropriately, and anyone can raise a dispute to the arbitrator in case the reviewer collides with the beneficiary to release the funds before the task has been completed. Reviewer can decide to return all or part of the funds to the DAO if the task is not been completed appropriately.

comment.body:
There are sooooo many alternatives outside of the Aragon UI to consider....
It is much better IMO to use an external escrow so that you can have interoperability for funding proposals. 

Imagine CV where external donors can donate directly to a proposal to lower the amount of conviction required because donating directly would change the Asking amount of the proposal

For Example: maybe a proposal asks for Y which makes the conviction X but then someone donates to the proposal so now the proposal is only asking for Y-D and the Conviction required is now less than X

I also prefer Conviction to be displayed as a DAI amount (using the Conviction and the trigger function you can derive a $ amount) but thats a side note....

here is a list of projects that could be interfaced with:
1. Giveth
2. Giveth 2.0 (doesn't exist.... yet)
3. Gitcoin
4. Bounties.network (which was just retired.. but the code is there!)
5 Cryptounlocked https://cryptounlocked.wetrust.io/
6. https://atstake.net/  
7. http://escrowmyether.com/
8. https://escrow.kleros.io/
9. https://spring.wetrust.io/ (not an escrow)
10. https://cryptocare.tech/ (not an escrow)

issue.title: Nested proposals
issue.body:
A nested proposal is a "forked" proposal, an alternative proposal that is built on top of a previous one. When supporting a nested proposal, you are supporting also the parent one (and all grandparents as we can have various levels, ending up with a tree of proposals).

The propose of this system is to allow people to tweak proposals and seek support without the risk of losing conviction in the change. Nested proposals compete among their siblings, but on the top level they represent a proposal that still receives all the conviction deposited in all their children.

Proposals could even have multiple parents, and contribute to them dividing the conviction received between them, but for the sake of clarity we are not going to implement this feature.

Nested proposals will appear in the frontend as any other proposal, with it's own number id, and a text linking to the "parent" idea. If we expand them (we go to their details page), we will see a list of siblings (similar and at the same time competing proposals), and another list with the children (proposals that may "improve" the current one and pool conviction towards it).

issue.title: Quadratic Conviction Voting
issue.body:
Quadratic voting is cutting edge nowadays. It has no previous relation with conviction voting but they can be combined very easily.

In some way, quadratic voting distributes voting power over people and conviction voting over time, or as @mzargham puts it, conviction voting address smoothing the way information is collected in time where as quadratic voting is reorganizing "in space" where the dimension of space is people.

Combined we get an algorithm which addresses distribution in both space and time. We have to take into account that we need a strong id in order to use quadratic voting (one account per user).

Applied to our current system, we only have to square root the staked tokens and multiply it by a scaling factor before we pass them as `oldAmount` param in the `calculateConviction(uint64 timePassed, uint256 lastConv, uint256 oldAmount)` function. A very simple and optional change that can have a lot of implications for communities that decide to go this way, giving more conviction power to small token holders.

It has a lot of sense to combine this with splitting the vote into various proposals (see #36).

issue.title: Allow users split their stake tokens among multiple proposals
issue.body:
This involves an extra panel to decide which percentage of your tokens a user wants to stake when supporting a proposal. It can be a [slider](https://ui.aragon.org/slider/) with a top in the right part that indicates the percentage of tokens already staked in other proposals.

![Screenshot from 2020-01-30 19-00-07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/931684/73476560-c9e90800-4392-11ea-9476-fc27a219ce1a.png)

We extend the supported proposal box not only with the amount of staked tokens but also with the percentage it represents. We also state the number and percentage of tokens not staked in any proposal.

We may want to move this box to the "Supported by me" tab since it may show more than one proposal (or add a filter).

issue.title: Optionally use a Payments app instead of a Vault to initialize the app
issue.body:
Conviction Voting app should be able to be initialized with an Escrow / Payments app (see #34) as well as a Vault app.

At this moment we are using the `vault.transfer()` and `vault.balance()` functions to transfer funds when a proposal is approved and watch the funds to calculate the threshold. These functions should also be available in the Payments app, being the vault functions available by object componentization or inheritance, still not clear:

* In the case of componentization, we could initialize CV with a Payments app that interfaces between CV and a Finance and/or a Vault/Agent apps. We could have the Payments app on top of Finance, or use it as a substitute of Finance.
  * In order to record the transfer in the Finance app, we should initialize the Payments app with a Finance instance as it is done by the [payroll app](https://github.com/1Hive/payroll-app#initialization) and use the function `finance.newImmediatePayment()` to retrieve the funds from the Vault.
  * `payments.transfer()` and `payments.balance()` should redirect to `payments.finance().newImmediatePayment()` and `payments.finance().vault().balance()` respectively.
* In the case of Vault inheritance, we would be doing a Vault on steroids (as Agent is). We would have all-in-one app: a vault, an interface similar to Finance to log the transfers, and the escrow functionality if desired.
  * It does not depend on any other app.
  * Payments is still a Vault, so it can contain the DAO funds and CV can use `vault.transfer()` and `vault.balance()`.

We will think on the Payments / Escrow app architecture a little more until we decide.

issue.title: Conviction Voting without money allocation

labels.name: product
labels.description: Discussion about integration of new features

issue.body:
For many use cases, no money allocation is needed for the first proposal that trespasses a certain threshold. We may only want to use conviction to prioritize a set of community ideas, or value a set of resources along time.

In this cases, no funding pool, no beneficiary, no requested funds, nor threshold formula are needed. We only have a list of proposals that is ordered by the conviction recollected from the stake token holders.

We can simplify the application way when no vault is set in the app initialization.

issue.title: Write tests
issue.body:
Consider a `vault` with 15000 DAI, and a `token` TKN with a total supply of 45000 (_root account_ has 30000 TKN and _user account_ has 15000 TKN).
 
Write a test with the following calls:
```javascript
api.addProposal('Conviction Voting', '0x', 1000, user, {from: root})
// on time 20
api.stakeToProposal(1, 1000, { from: root })
// on time 30
api.stakeToProposal(1, 1000, { from: user })
// on time 50
api.withdrawFromProposal(1, 1000, { from: root })
// on time 60
api.stakeToProposal(1, 6000, {from: user})
// on time 100
api.enactProposal(1);
```
It should pass.

Repeat the test for proposal 2:
```javascript
api.addProposal('Aragon Sidechain', '0x', 2000, root, {from: user})
```
It should not pass.

comment.body: Thank you so much for your work again, @SabaunT.

```javascript

// on time 30
```

comment.body:
> It means that for tests we should increase block number for x10 (20, 50 e.t.c) times, doesn't it?

Conviction is time dependent, so between one call and the next we need to mine the number of blocks that are stated in the comment, yes.

> do you mean requestedToken by TKN?

No, stakeToken is TKN and requestedToken is DAI for this test.

comment.body:
Yes, it means to execute after a certain number of blocks. I think this [can be achieved](https://medium.com/edgefund/time-travelling-truffle-tests-f581c1964687) with the `evm_mine` function.

On the other hand, stake token, funds token and vault should also be mocked (because now the app is initialized with them set at `0x0`).
